New ceria solid solutions (Cu0.08Mn0.02MxCe0.9-xO2) were proposed: as an additional stabilizer (dopant), iron/cobalt/nickel was introduced into the system in an amount of x = 0.05–0.20. These catalysts were evaluated in oxidation of CO to study lattice oxygen mobility. Since the catalysts being developed can be universal, they were used in the degradation reaction of organic dyes in water (Fenton process), since iron-type-containing catalysts have proven themselves well for this process. The main active center in CO oxidation is Cu+, and in Fenton process is Fe2+, but it is possible to obtain a catalyst that has different most active centers in its composition, and has high activity in different oxidation processes, but must consist of a ceria solid solution with dopants of multivalent cations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ceria Transition metals CO oxidation Fenton process Data availability The data supporting this article have been included as part of the ESI. 1 Introduction Ceria-based materials have paid attention due to unique characteristics. The ability to undergo oxidation/reduction reactions, which allows for the release or storage of oxygen, is a special feature of ceria. Its catalytic properties are largely influenced by the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycle and are affected by some factors, such as high specific surface area, preferential exposure of reactive facets, oxygen vacancies, and most significant, type\quantity of dopants [1,2]; thus, doping ceria with various types of cations increases redox properties and the number of oxygen vacancies, thereby improving catalytic performance [3,4]. Recent studies show that ceria catalytic activity can be significantly enhanced by incorporating transition metals into ceria crystal lattice to form a solid solution [5]. When these metals are introduced to ceria, a synergistic effect leads to increased catalytic activity, with the most pronounced effect occurring when manganese and/or copper are used [6,7]. A specific amount and ratio of Mn and\or Cu significantly boost ceria catalytic activity and stability [8]. Further addition of dopants can improve the catalytic properties of the CuMnCeOx solid solution [9–11]. Despite this, the search for the optimal combination of dopants continues. Among the cheapest and most promising metals are the iron triad: iron, cobalt, and nickel. Doping ceria with them leads to sufficient activity in various catalytic processes, making such systems universal in various reactions [12,13]. Compared to noble and rare-earth metals, such transition metals were regarded as potential alternatives due to their notable low-temperature activity, thermal stability, and some resistance to poisoning [14,15]; so, iron, cobalt, and nickel ions with similar ionic radii, but quite different chemical nature, are chosen. Typically, the addition of cobalt improves the oxidation properties, while at the same time the addition of nickel and iron is suitable for processes of hydrocarbon conversion, hydrogenation, oxidation of organic dyes and antibiotics in wastewater (such as the Fenton process) [16–20]. The redox and catalytic properties of ceria and its composite oxides are primarily dependent upon various factors such as phase modification, structural defects/distortion (lattice), and chemical non-stoichiometry. Inspired by the unique and promising characteristics of ceria-based mixed oxides and solid solutions for various applications, a systematic study is necessary for understanding [21]. Here, examination of the properties of novel Cu-Mn-(Fe/Ni/Co)-Ce-O materials will be presented in the work. To compare the catalytic properties, the oxidation reactions of CO and an organic dye (carmoisine, Fenton process) were chosen as test reactions to assess the prospects of such materials. The solubility of iron, cobalt and nickel will also be assessed and how such solid solutions will be stable and effective under such conditions: influence on the structure, oxygen storage capacity, catalytic activity… 2 Material and methods The Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Mn(NO3)2·4H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Fe(NO3)3∙9H2O, Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O, and Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (Acros Organics) compounds were used as initial salts. Appropriate amounts of salts were dissolved in concentrated nitric acid (68 %) with the concentration of salts of 0.667 M. After the dissolution of the salts, this mixture was added to distilled water, giving a concentration of 0.1 M. Then, the co-precipitation was carried out by the addition of 2.5 M KOH solution up to pH 11. Ultrasonic processing (35 kHz, 150 W) was used during all processes at 30 °C under stirring. The resulting precipitates were filtered, washed with a distilled water-ethanol solution (H2O/C2H5OH=9 vol.), dried at 150 °C for 12 h, and calcined in static air by heating at a rate of 4 °C/min from room temperature to 500 °C and kept for 1 h in a muffle furnace [8–11]. All powders were characterized by XRD (DRON-3 M, CuKα radiation), TEM (Jeol JEM-2100F, 200 kV), low temperature adsorption of nitrogen (TriStar 3000 Micromeritics, BET-BJH at 77 K), Raman spectroscopy (Horiba LabRAM Evolution, room temperature, 532 nm), XPS (Axis Ultra DLD Kratos, Al Kα radiation at an X-ray gun power of 150 W). The catalytic activity of the samples in the oxidation of CO was determined by the flow method at atmospheric pressure. The process was conducted in a U-shaped quartz reactor at the total flow rate of 60 ml/min within a temperature range of 20–500 °C (at a certain temperature, measurements were carried out at least 3 times with isothermal holding when equilibrium was reached). The temperature was measured with a thermocouple placed in the center of the catalytic bed. The catalyst sample mass was 0.3 g. The model gas mixture had the following composition, vol. %: CO – 1; O2 – 2; N2 – 97. The concentrations of gases were determined by a gas chromatograph (Crystallux-4000 M). Model solutions of dye carmoisine (azorubine) was used for oxidation. The dye content in the solution was determined using a spectrophotometer (KFK-3). The concentration was calculated according to the calibration graphs. The emission wavelength for carmoisine was 517 nm. The Fenton process was carried out in a beaker with a stirrer at a solution temperature of 60 °C. A dye solution with an initial concentration of 20 mg/l and a volume of 50 ml was additionally acidified with a 1 M hydrochloric acid solution to pH=5. The mass of the catalyst used was 0.1 g. The amount of hydrogen peroxide with a concentration of 3 wt. % was 0.15 ml at the initial moment, then the same amount of peroxide was injected every 10 min. A sample of the decolorized solution was taken and placed in a cuvette to determine the optical density and then returned to the original solution. The content of metals in the catalysts (before and after reaction) was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on an Agilent 5800 VDV spectrometer. The conversion (purification) value of CO or carmoisine was calculated using the standard formula: α=(C0 C)/C0, where C0 is the initial concentration, C is the concentration at the current moment. 3 Results and discussion First, the solubility of additional dopants and the formation of a solid solution were assessed using XRD (Fig. 1 , Table 1 ). Thus, for nickel and cobalt, the formation of a second oxide phase occurs almost immediately, in addition to the solid solution, which is confirmed by both a change in the lattice parameter (a small part is still built into the ceria lattice) and microstrain (Table S1). In turn, iron seems to be well integrated into the lattice; only when its content is high, it begins to displace copper (CuO is formed on the surface). There is also a tendency to first increase and then decrease the lattice parameter (Fig. S1), so there is no clear observation of Vegard’s law. The ionic radii of Fe3+/Fe2+ (0.645/0.78 Å), Co3+/Co2+ (0.61/0.745 Å), Ni2+ (0.69 Å) are smaller than that of Ce4+/Ce3+ (0.97/1.143 Å; Shannon radii in coordination VI for small transition metals and VIII for cerium in ceria fluorite structure). In this case, the parameter values for cobalt and nickel mainly fluctuate around the initial lattice parameter of the system Cu0.08Mn0.02Ce0.9O2, despite the fact that all three metal ions have quite similar ionic radii. This may be caused by: cerium cation reduction from 4+ to 3+, appropriate decrease in O 2p-Ce 4f hybridization; surface stress due to difference of coordination between atoms on the surface and in the bulk; the connection between the different ionic states of iron triad metals and corresponding doping limits in ceria lattice [12,22–24]. Also, nanocrystalline ceria showed non-monotonic variation of the lattice parameter with decreasing particle size; and this is attributed to a combination of two opposing effects lattice contraction and lattice expansion due to enhanced surface tension and bonding weakening, so these opposite trends point to the existence of a minimum value for the unit cell parameters in nanocrystalline ceria [25–27]. Additional doping leads to an increase in surface area (Fig. S2, Table 1), however, each of the dopants has its own effect on this trend. For iron-containing systems there is no clear dependence on the proportion of dopant, the only thing is that with the appearance of the second phase of CuO the specific surface area decreases somewhat (samples Fe15 and Fe20). For systems with nickel, its additional introduction does not particularly affect the surface size. And in cobalt systems, the specific surface area of the solid solution Co05 is slightly higher than that of the sample Co10 due to the appearance of the second phase of cobalt oxide, but then the surface increases due to more developed surface of Co3O4. Similar trends are observed for the pore size distribution (Fig. S3): the appearance of the second phase somewhat narrows the distribution, but a further increase in this oxide phase leads to a wide distribution. The pore size distribution of these systems is not uniform, and the range of it is wide (2–30 nm; at the same time, according to the t-plot method, there are no micropores). As a rule, the surface of iron-containing systems is somewhat lower than that of cobalt/nickel [15,19,28]. In previous works the Fe-Ce-O catalysts has the highest surface and pore volume, and the doping of Co is more obvious to reduce these [29]. In our case it is the other way around, and apparently depends on the method of synthesis and the “degree of incorporation” and distribution in the ceria lattice. The powders were composed of particle aggregates (Fig. 2 ), with connected near-spherical nanoparticles ranging from approximately 3 to 10 nm. This corresponds to the crystallite size calculated using the Scherrer equation (dXRD, Table 1). No differences were found between the particles of the fresh systems Fe05, Ni05, and Co05. Also, electron diffraction (SAED, Fig. S4) does not show any additional phases, even in the case of sample Ni05 (possibly due to the locality of the method). Additionally, the distribution of elements is shown (mapping in STEM mode, Fig. S5): it is clear that the dopants are conditionally evenly distributed over the surface of as-prepared samples, i.e. “local” grouping of these elements is not noticeable, correspondingly indirectly confirming the formation of a solid solution. Further analysis of the formation of solid solutions was considered using Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 3 ). The introduction of a dopant into the ceria lattice leads to crystal imperfections, which in turn affect the oxygen environment surrounding the metal ion. The following bands are characteristic of ceria: 460 cm-1 – F2g vibration mode of the cubic fluorite; 540 cm-1 – defect space, including oxygen vacancy; 600 cm-1 – vacancy-interstitial oxygen defects [30,31]. The shift in the F2g vibration mode indicates lattice distortion due to cell contraction (blue line shows the shift), which is caused by the difference in ionic radii between the dopants and Ce4+, and this agrees with the lattice parameter. The ratio of Ov/F2g (I600/I460, Table S1) represents the concentration of oxygen vacancies and this is a determining factor for the catalytic activity. Mδ+ cations enter into the ceria lattice, leading to a larger amount of oxygen vacancies. It is clear that it is the addition of nickel that increases this indicator, and therefore forms a more defective structure. The effect of additional doping was first assessed in the CO oxidation reaction (Fig. 4 ). It is clear that only the systems Fe05 and Fe10 exhibit better activity in complete oxidation (temperature T100 % is lower) compared to the original system. However, at the initial stage, at low oxidation state, the CO conversion is higher precisely in the case of low doping (x = 0.05). An additional increase in dopant content results in a decline in activity, likely due to a reduction in the quantity of more active copper and manganese in the subsurface layer [10,11]. The variations in the formation energy of surface oxygen vacancies, the nature and quantity of low-coordination and defect sites, are thought to be the key factors influencing the surface-dependent behaviors of CO interaction, as well as lattice oxygen reactivity and mobility, thereby affecting the CO oxidation performance [32]. Iron, cobalt, and nickel-based systems are commonly used in environmentally friendly processes, such as Fenton-like degradation catalysts for dye removal. These systems are effective because they can catalyze the degradation of H2O2, generating OH˙. The hydroxyl radical is a green, non-selective oxidant, but the rate-limiting step in the process is the regeneration of Mδ+–1 to Mδ+ [33]. The degradation of carmoisine was assessed by monitoring the change in the optical density of the dye solution over time (Fig. 5 ). The kinetics was investigated, using the Behnajady-Modirshahla-Ghanbary [34] and first-order kinetic models (as a rule, they adequately describe the process). The linear equation of these models follows: t 1 − C / C O = m + bt and − ln ( C / C O ) = kt where C (mg/l) – dye concentration at time t (min), Co – initial concentration, m and b – the reaction kinetics and oxidation capacity, k is the kinetic constant. Analysis showed (Fig. S6) that the kinetic model, correctly describing the kinetic of discoloration of carmoisine solution, was the Behnajady-Modirshahla-Ghanbary model, as in previous studies [35–37]. The physical significance of 1/m and 1/b are the initial degradation rate and the maximum oxidation capacity of a catalyst at the end of reactions, respectively. The correlation coefficients (R2) of the linear fitting of the model show the highest R2 (>0.99), that is, this model is good for description and fitting. When compared with other proposed catalysts [35–38], our systems showed similar or better activity with almost the same process parameters, although these systems were studied at pH=5, which is closer to a neutral environment and requires less acid consumption, since catalysis is mainly carried out at pH=3 for achieving better efficiency. This is how a comparison was made at these pH values for the system Fe05 (Fig. 5): at the initial stage of oxidation, the advantages are noticeable in more acidic conditions, but complete oxidation of carmoisine is better in solution at pH=5. Also, without a catalyst, only with the addition of peroxide, the discoloration is only 20 % after 100 min, which means this is not an effective approach, so the presence of a catalyst is a necessary condition for this process. The stability and reusability were analyzed by recycling it for 3 periods. The activity during the last recirculation period corresponds to the activity for a fresh catalyst, the catalyst can have high stability and reuse properties in the process. The toxicity of the resulting products is usually lower than that of the original dye, since the main problem is the azo group, which is the first to undergo oxidation during the reaction [38]. During the Fenton process partial leaching of metals occurs and they can then be easily removed from the solution by precipitation (raising the pH); so, the proposed catalysts can be easily further extracted, calcined (regenerated) and reused. Thus, systems with a small addition of iron (Fe05 and Fe10) turned out to be the most active. Apparently, this is due to both the formation of a large number of oxygen vacancies and also easy redox mobility in the Cu2+/Cu+↔Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+↔Fe3+/Fe2+↔Ce4+/Ce3+ chain [39]. So, after the oxidation of CO, no significant changes occur to the catalyst; it remains stable. In the case of oxidation of carmoisine, partial leaching of metals into solution actually occurs, which happens with all available catalysts in the Fenton process. Although the particle size remains constant (Fig. 2), there is an increase in the lattice parameter (Table 1) and a decrease in the specific surface area (accordingly, a change in nitrogen sorption and pore size distribution; Table 1, Fig. 6 ), but the formation of some new phases does not occur (Fig. 6, Fig. S4). In these catalysts, it is copper that begins to be washed out faster, and iron to a lesser extent (cerium also is, but in insignificant quantities [36]), as shown by elemental analysis (Table 2 ); in turn the distribution of copper and manganese remains more uniform (Fig. S5). In general, after oxidation reactions the catalyst remains stable and highly efficient, although the number of oxygen vacancies slightly decreases (Fig 3, Table S1). To study the surface and the changes occurring to it, the XPS method was used. As previously established, the surface of ceria is enriched with small-radius metal cations (Table 2), it is evident that the number of dopants is somewhat higher on the surface than in the total volume (ICP). In this case, after the oxidation of CO, there are no significant changes in the composition of the surface, while after the Fenton process, a “significant restructuring” of the surface occurs: it is enriched significantly with copper and a little with iron, confirming that it is mainly copper that is washed out of the solid solution of ceria. Fig. 7 shows the Ce 3d spectra of the studied samples and Table S2 contains characteristics of photoelectron peaks. The spectra were fitted based on the data presented in [40] and in our previous works [10,39,41]. For peak designations we used the traditionally used nomenclature [42]. It should be noted that at present there is no unified approach to the interpretation of photoelectron spectra of Ce 3d of CeOx compounds. As a rule, the Ce 3d spectra are presented as the sum of Ce3+ and Ce4+ states. According to the theory, the Ce3+ and Ce4+ states should be described by four and six peaks corresponding to two and three spin-orbit doublets, which suggests that the spectra are presented as the sum of an even number of peaks. In a number of cases, the authors present the experimental spectra as the sum of the experimental spectra of the supposed Ce2O3 and CeO2 compounds. In those cases where this is not possible, the Ce 3d spectra are described as a set of both Gaussian and Lorentzian profiles. Paparazzo [43,44], analyzing various options for approximating Ce 3d spectra, notes that the number of the profiles used ranges from 4 to 11. Unfortunately, in all the works cited by Paparazzo, there are no data on the peak widths and, in a large number of cases, data on the relative peak intensities, which does not allow an adequate comparison of the results presented in them in terms of the reliability of the description of the spectra and their interpretation. Our analysis of numerous spectra of Ce 3d samples presented in the literature as CeO2 or Ce2O3 showed that none of the spectra can be adequately described by six or four Gaussian peaks, provided that the spectra are recorded with high resolution. The absence of reliable reference Ce 3d spectra of CeO2 and Ce2O3 in the literature creates difficulties in the application of factor analysis [45]. It should be noted that in our approximation of the Ce 3d spectra, as in the other works [40,46,47], the peak V, which is absent in the works analyzed by us, is distinguished, and in the first two, the peak u0, traditionally attributed to the state of Ce3+, is missing. Since the energy intervals between the peaks V and I are close to the interval v”’ – v, the peak V and, accordingly, the peak I should be attributed to defects, the nature of which requires further clarification. Conventionally, the fractions of the Ce4+ state in the fresh/CO/Fenton samples are 0.76/0.79/0.76. The remaining share is Ce3+ in the general case, but most likely when decomposing the spectrum also pay attention to the share of defects. It should be noted that, in our opinion, there is no clear definition in the literature of what the authors mean by the state of Ce3+, when the spectrum attributed to them is described by two peaks instead of four, characteristic of Ce2O3, or when the intensity ratio of the peaks v0/v’/u0/u’ differs greatly from that recorded for Ce2O3. In interpreting the spectra of Ce 3d in ceria solid solutions, the following approaches can be distinguished, depending on the shape of the spectrum (Fig. S7): 1) The spectrum can be presented as a set of spectra of Ce2O3 and CeO2, obtained in one way or another. It is well known that when CeO2 is exposed under ultra-high vacuum conditions X-ray radiation or heat treatment reduction with H2 or ion bombardment as a result of oxygen removal, Ce4+ is transformed into Ce3+, while the recorded spectrum of Ce 3d becomes similar in shape to the spectrum of La2O3 [48]. During subsequent oxidation of the resulting product, the reverse process Ce3+ → Ce4+ is observed [43,49–53]. 2) The spectrum is described by the sum of ten peaks, but cannot be represented as a set of Ce2O3 spectra and the relative intensities of peaks v0, v’, u0, and u’ differ noticeably from those characteristics of Ce2O3 [4,54,55]. Fig. 7 shows the Cu 2p3/2 spectra of the studied samples and Table S3 contains characteristics of photoelectron peaks. The spectra were fitted with six Gaussian profiles according to [56,57]. Based on the binding energies of peak I [58], it is assigned to the Cu+ state, whereas the other peaks point to the Cu2+ state, the main identifier of which is the satellite fitted by peaks IV, V and VI. Comparison of the binding energies, widths, relative intensities, and the shape of band relative intensities of the satellite peaks with literature data indicates the presence of a mixture of CuO and Cu(OH)2 in the samples. The fractions of the Cu+ state in the fresh/CO/Fenton samples are 0.20/0.22/0.21; thus, the charge state of copper does not change, but as indicated above, only the amount on the surface. The Mn 2p3/2 spectra (Fig. 7, Table S4) were approximated with four peaks attributed to Mn2+, Mn3+, Mn4+ states, and satellite [59–61]. Due to the low concentration of Mn and, accordingly, the low signal-to-noise ratio, the relative intensities of the charge states of Mn atoms are semiquantitative and the Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ ratios are estimated 0.29/0.36/0.35 (fresh), 0.28/0.32/0.40 (CO), 0.27/0.29/0.44 (Fenton). It is evident that in comparison with the state of copper, manganese is gradually oxidized to the state of Mn4+, thus, in addition to iron, it is also the “motor” of oxidation reactions (electron exchange). Also, the effects of multiplet splitting, peak asymmetry, core-hole lifetime, shake-up processes, and crystal-field splitting in the spectrum have not been accounted for because of insufficient energy resolution [59–61]. Now let's look at what happens to the iron on the surface of the catalyst (Fig. 7, Table S5). The main characteristics of the Fe 2p photoelectron spectra are the binding energies of the main peaks and satellites, spin-orbit splitting and relative intensities of the satellites. Due to the low signal-to-noise ratio caused by the low iron concentration, an attempt was made to reliably determine these parameters as a first approximation by describing the spectra as a sum of two states, namely Fe2+ and Fe3+, using the reference spectra of FeO and Fe2O3. The basis for this approach was the presence of a shoulder in the region of low binding energies of about 709.4 eV and a satellite with a binding energy of about 718 eV. Under the condition of the best description of the low-energy region, the FeO spectrum was fitted into the spectra of the fresh and CO samples. Due to the absence of a shoulder in the spectrum of the Fenton sample, such an operation was not carried out. At the same time, it was found impossible to fit the spectrum of Fe2O3 into the spectra of all samples due to the difference in the energy intervals between the main peak and the satellite in the spectra of Fe2O3 and the studied samples, which differ by approximately 1 eV. Since the intervals Fe 2p3/2 sat – Fe 2p3/2 in the spectra of Fe2O3 and FeOOH are close [62–64], this indicates a noticeable manifestation of the nearest environment on multiplet splitting. Based on the approximation of the spectra, the proportions of Fe2+ in the fresh/CO/Fenton samples are 0.14/0.09/0. Thus, a similar picture occurs as with manganese: oxidation to Fe3+, and after the Fenton process this share is 100 %, i.e. the process of regeneration to Fe2+ is indeed the limiting stage; but the process, as can be seen from the catalyst tests, is stable, i.e. the need to add hydrogen peroxide for a heterogeneous catalyst is a necessary element of the functioning of a ceria-based catalyst. It is also possible that cerium also promotes the oxidation of low-charge cations into high-charge ones, since it is shown that the metallic active sites M can be oxidized to MOx by lattice oxygen from ceria support – the spillover effect, induced by strong metal-support interaction [65,66]. It is known that it is M = O that most likely reacts with CO (copper species have especially the lowest energy among all transition and rare earth metals; Cu+ ion is adsorption center for CO molecules via π-bonding); other active sites, M-O-Ce and Ce=O react with CO at elevated temperatures also, generating oxygen vacancies and producing CO2. The formation of M-Ov-Ce plays a beneficial role in promoting the decomposition of molecular oxygen, among other things. However, the decomposition of carbonate remains the rate-limiting step that influences the activation of M-□-Ce [67–70]. In this way, the CO oxidation reaction follows the Mars–van Krevelen mechanism: the CO adsorbed on the catalyst surface reacts with the lattice oxygen, forming CO2 and creating oxygen vacancy, the latter in turn adsorbs the oxygen species so that O2 is activated to participate in the reaction as a new lattice oxygen [71]. While as is known other cations (Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+, Fe2+/Fe3+, Co2+/Co3+, Ni2+/Ni3+, Ni2+ is generally stable and its switching to Ni3+ is not clearly determined) somewhat more difficult to adsorb molecules of CO; and possible explanation of this phenomenon is the lower thermal stability of the M-CO species [3,72]. So, according to the IR data, the following groups are characteristic: bicarbonate (HCO3 -), monodentate carbonate (CO3 2-), bidentate carbonate (OCO), CO, and CO2. Monodentate and bidentate carbonates are the most characteristic and the first is more easily gasified than the last. At the same time, formate groups are not excluded as intermediate species [67,73,74]. As reported, the thermal stability of these species is in the order: bridged carbonate < bidentate carbonate < inorganic carboxylate < monodentate carbonate species. The decomposition rate of the carbonate species for each catalyst could provide a measure to evaluate its catalytic activity of CO oxidation. This could be because some active sites are easily blocked by the produced carbonate-like species on catalyst surface, causing catalyst deactivation during the reaction. In turn, the rapid decomposition of the carbonate species could create reactive sites again [75]. As shown earlier, under oxygen-rich conditions (our case), the extended O2 residence time promotes the formation of active oxygen and Ce4+ species at the surface; therefore, the sustained CO2 production in these conditions, despite low Ce3+ concentration, suggests synergistic activity between activated oxygen (Ce4+ - O 2p) and Ce3+ species [76]. As can be seen, this is in good agreement with the XPS data on the quantitative/qualitative composition of surface cations. In Fenton process the catalyst with a large surface area and porous texture facilitates the dye adsorption and provides more accessible active sites for the activation of hydrogen peroxide. The metal cation species are involved in the reactions, which are described as follows (here metal is a catalyst cation and not in solution): (1) Mδ+–1 + H2O2 → Mδ+ + OH- + OH˙ (2) OH˙ + dye → intermediates → CO2 + H2O (3) OH˙ + H2O2 → HO2 ˙ + H2O (4) OH˙ + HO2 ˙ → O2 + H2O (5) OH˙ + Mδ+–1 → Mδ+ + OH- (6) Mδ++ H2O2 → M-OOHδ+–1 + H + (7) M-OOHδ+–1 → HO2 ˙ + Mδ+–1 (8) Mδ+–1 + HO2 ˙ → Mδ+ + HO2 - (9) Mδ+ + HO2 ˙ → Mδ+–1 + H + + O2 The main pair of cations playing a role in the Fenton process is Fe2+/Fe3+, the rest also participate in similar reactions, but to a lesser extent in the absence of iron (according to published works, the activity decreases in the following series: Fe>Co>Ni) [77]; so, the synergy of co-doped catalysts is explained by the simultaneous action of the heterogeneous pairs involved in reactions 1 and 6–7 [78]. During the process, the regeneration of Fe2+ is the rate-controlling step, therefore, the presence of other multivalent cations in the composition of catalysts promotes regeneration; this is similar to the process of CO oxidation, only the active centers are Cu+, and in Fenton are Fe2+, i.e. the presence of the following reactions is extremely necessary (at the same time, as can be seen, the addition of cobalt/nickel has little effect on the activity of complete oxidation of the dye): (10) Fe3+/Fe2+↔Cu2+/Cu+↔Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+↔Ce4+/Ce3+ In this way, it is possible to obtain a catalyst that has different active centers in its composition, and has high activity in different oxidation processes, but its base must consist of a ceria solid solution with additives of multivalent cations. 4 Conclusions The dependence of the third doping element, iron, cobalt or nickel, as well as its amount on the catalytic properties in the oxidation reactions of CO and carmoisine is considered. From the presented data it is evident that the most universal catalysts are the Cu0.08Mn0.02Fe0.05Ce0.85O2 and Cu0.08Mn0.02Fe0.10Ce0.80O2 systems. A combination of several factors plays in their favor: a large number of oxygen vacancies, increasing the active sites on the catalyst subsurface through forwarded doping, a synergistic effect of Mδ+-Ce4+ due to facile electron exchange, and also easy redox mobility (Cu2+/Cu+↔Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+↔Fe3+/Fe2+↔Ce4+/Ce3+). However, despite the different most active catalytic centers, it is possible to select/combine such a catalyst, in particular the one proposed here, which is suitable exactly for different oxidation reactions, but the catalyst itself must necessarily be based on a solid solution of ceria. coredata.dc:description: New ceria solid solutions (Cu0.08Mn0.02MxCe0.9-xO2) were proposed: as an additional stabilizer (dopant), iron/cobalt/nickel was introduced into the system in an amount of x = 0.05–0.20. These catalysts were evaluated in oxidation of CO to study lattice oxygen mobility. Since the catalysts being developed can be universal, they were used in the degradation reaction of organic dyes in water (Fenton process), since iron-type-containing catalysts have proven themselves well for this process. The main active center in CO oxidation is Cu+, and in Fenton process is Fe2+, but it is possible to obtain a catalyst that has different most active centers in its composition, and has high activity in different oxidation processes, but must consist of a ceria solid solution with dopants of multivalent cations.
